utterances: So what this group did, is they - back on Earth - they simulated the chemical composition of Titan, all these the methane and nitrogen - and then instead of sort of using ultraviolet light from the sun, they used radio waves to try to spark a reaction.

And when they did this - and they didn't need water, and they didn't need lightning like in some other classic experiments - they produced nucleotide bases, which make up DNA and RNA, and they also found amino acids.
And what they're thinking - they dont know - is that these large compounds that have not been identified on Titan, may be these amino acids and these nucleotide bases.
They now have to go back with another spacecraft that can really that's what they want to do, go back and really identify and see for sure.
But what's really neat is that this is saying perhaps that life - not just at Titan, maybe life throughout the solar system - really began up in the air, up in the sky, even on Earth.
Maybe we didn't need liquid pools of water on the ground.
Maybe the first reaction that gave compounds that supported life, was in the atmosphere, not on the ground in water.
Is there any water in the Titan atmosphere?
There wouldn't be Titan is frozen.
If there is any water, it would have frozen.
And what they say is that the methane on Titan is what water is on Earth.
So no, there wouldn't be much water, and it would be all frozen out.
So this shows you that you don't need to have water to create those building blocks of life.
That's right.
That's what this seems to say.
So that's really, really exciting.
Wow, and we always said about Titan, that this was a place to go visit more.
You know, here's some more emails that we're getting.
This one comes from Ramona.
She says: The most memorable moment was the Michael Jackson ""Thriller"" video.
It was so fresh and set a much higher standard for music video entertainment.

And a lot of people don't know, or maybe they do, how important a role Michael Jackson actually played with the development of MTV and music video and getting black artists into the mix, because when MTV began, it was rock music exclusively, pretty much.
And it wasn't until a couple of years later that black artists like Michael Jackson began to get in there, and this video right here was one of the things that opened the door.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""BILLIE JEAN"")
(Singing) People always told me be careful what you do, and don't go around breaking young girls' hearts.
And mother always told me be careful of who you love, and be careful of what you do because the lie becomes the truth.
Billie Jean is not my lover.
She's just a girl who claims that I am the one.
So give us some idea: How did the people that ran MTV in the beginning, how did they decide what to put on and what not to put on?
Well, in the beginning, of course, as I was saying earlier, Tony, there weren't that many videos to choose from.
So I mean, there was some, you know, independently-made ones that were good, some things that were just OK.
But they would put everything on in the beginning.
And, of course, the more people discovered the channel, the more powerful the channel became in helping shape the tastes of music fans all over America.
You're right about the Michael Jackson ""Thriller"" video.
Not only was ""Billie Jean"" the one that actually blew everybody away and started sending the album ""Thriller"" into the stratosphere, but you're right, it opened the door for black artists.
Before that, it was definitely more, you know, leaning towards rock and, you know, new wave music that was out at that time.
And that changed - literally changed everything.
And I think everybody who was around back then remembers where they were the night that ""Thriller"" debuted, because it was an event.
Absolutely.
You know, we have a handful of emails and a line just - people lined up to talk to, so let's go to some of them.
This is Camille(ph) calling from Franklin, Massachusetts.
Hello, Camille.
Hi.
I distinctly remember being 11 or 12 watching Billy Idol's ""White Wedding"" and loving it.
And my mom came in and she's a staunch Catholic and she flipped out when she saw it because she said it was a black mass or something satanic.
And she grounded us from MTV.
It was probably only a month but it felt like a year.
Wow.
That's amazing.
A great story.
Thank you for that.
We mentioned that you, Matt, were doing - were and are doing ""120 Minutes."" The next caller is somebody that I think remembers you.
This is Bill from Loveland, Colorado.
Hello, Bill.
Hey, there.
Hey, Bill.
How are you?
I'm doing good.

My memory is discovering ""120 Minutes."" Having grown up in Des Moines, Iowa, which unfortunately in the mid-'80s was a radio wasteland, all we had available was rock and roll, classic rock, easy listening and top 40 stuff, and I never was able to appreciate or get into that.
And then discovering Matt and some of the artists that you featured early on, it opened my world up to what music could be and still is, in my opinion.
How about that?
That's pretty nice, isn't it?
No, absolutely.
And thank you so much.
I really do appreciate that.

And I feel that's one of the things that was magical about ""120,"" and is again, because you know, I was talking to a journalist from The New York Times who said to me the reason why ""120"" back then was so influential was because, you know, the only places that you could find a lot of that music was on college radio, at your independent record store, or on ""120 Minutes"" and - or in fanzines.
And now because there's so much information out there, it's a good curation, a place to go for those two hours to hear it.
But I thank you so much for saying that.

And I want to say that, you know, everybody from Jack White to Jack Black to the Black Keys, all these artists, actors and just people that I meet everywhere say how much ""120 Minutes,"" you know, influenced their musical taste.
And you know, it's just - for me that's one of the most flattering things.
And I'm just grateful that I've gotten the opportunity to host it in the past, and then I'm doing it again.
So I really appreciate your call.
So Matt, there was ""120,"" of course, and then, in 1993, MTV introduced these guys.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, ""BEAVIS AND BUTT-HEAD"")
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
And they're back as well.
Beavis and Butt-head.
Yeah.
The show's set to make a comeback in October.
We have a caller, actually, who wants to talk a little bit about ""Beavis and Butt-head."" This is Matt from Clarksville, Tennessee.
Go ahead, Matt.
Welcome.
Hi.
Yeah.
I listen to your show almost every night, except when I'm not working.
But I enjoyed the MTV through the '80s in high school.
And then shortly after that, the ""Beavis and Butt-head"" had - was issued and I watched, you know, almost religiously, but - and really enjoyed them a lot.
But when MTV got into the reality TV, I just didn't watch it anymore.
But those - the ""Beavis and Butt-heads"" were classics, I guess, for my generation and I really enjoyed it.
Thank you very much for that, Matt.

Let me ask you, though, Matt Pinfield, when a situation like this happens with a revolutionary new media concept, like MTV was, it goes through growing pains, does it not, and evolves, and some things work and some things don't.
Over your recollection, what has worked well for them and what hasn't worked so well?

Well, I mean, I think that, you know, because of the fact that, you know, the music video, when it first was introduced - I mean, I guess, music video has really go back to, you know, the Beatles doing, you know, ""Paperback Writer"" and, you know, ""Strawberry Fields"" and ""Penny Lane"" and all the things they did, they were music promo clips that were done in the 1960s.

But I think, you know, the things that have worked for them, obviously, are - the Video Music Awards has become, you know, a landmark staple thing for them - it's coming up again in just a few weeks, and of course the movie awards as well.
And I mean, a lot of people's careers started at MTV, like Denis Leary, who now, of course, you see on ""Rescue Me,"" Jon Stewart, Adam Sandler.
So a lot of people got their breaks there.
So, you know, those are the kind of things that have worked out well for them.
You know, MTV is actually the people that discovered reality TV very much by accident.
Because like it or not, they were going to do a soap opera, and they literally realized after that that they did work, going to be paying union actors to act in it.
So they had this house and this production team ready to go and they said, oh, you know what?
Why don't we put an ad in, you know, like Soundstage or Variety and see if some people will come and do this thing.
And literally, they got all those admissions and then that's how ""The Real World"" season one started.
So it was actually reality TV, like it or not, was started by accident.
You know, let me read some of these emails.
There are so many that I don't have time to get to all of them, but we'll give a few of them a shout out.
This is from Will in Citrus Heights, California.
The strongest memory that I have of MTV was when Nirvana came on the scene and changed the game - changed the glam rock scene forever.
Paradoxically, the next big memory was hearing Kurt Loder on ""MTV News"" announced the death of Kurt Cobain.
Here's another one from Ben Marino(ph).
He says: As a nine-year-old boy in a pink house, a la John Mellencamp in Indiana, I remember the debut well.
My boyhood friend Phil and I scheduled a sleepover.
The pink house was his, he goes on to say, just to stay up and watch the video of this new music channel.
I remember the rocket blasting off, astronaut planting the MTV flag and the unforgettable guitar riff that accompanied the beginning of the music video era.
It seems like a lifetime ago.
Here's another one from Claudia Miller(ph) in Kent, Ohio: I remember coming home from work one day about five years ago, my husband Jim saying, you got to see this.
He had recorded OK Go, treading to their song ""Here It Goes Again."" As we watched, we just laughed louder and louder.
It was so hilarious.
We were rolling on the floor.
That's my pick.
Now, this is another one I want to read.
I'm going to direct it towards you, Matt, because the person says - it's - let me see who it is.
It's Susan Adams.
She emailed to say: For me, it was the introduction of Jon Stewart.
Looking back, that was their lasting legacy since they have abandoned music.
Do you think MTV has abandoned music?

Well, I mean, obviously there's less of it shown than there originally was and - but not completely, especially if they hired me back again to do ""120 Minutes,"" because you know, me, I'm a music enthusiast, not a musical elitist.
And I love music and I love turning people on to it and talking about it.
So, you know, they haven't completely abandoned it, obviously, because they brought me back in.
Obviously there's less of it.
And look, I'm more of a drama fan than I am a reality TV fan.
I'd rather watch ""Dexter"" and ""Law & Order: Criminal Intent"" than a reality show.
But you know, it's been very successful for them.

But, you know, I obviously am a big fan of the music, but nobody can discount the effect that MTV has had on helping break artists over the years, whether it goes back to the beginning with Billy Idol and Duran Duran or, you know, he mentioned, you know, the glam hair metal days, bands like Bon Jovi and Poison, and then, of course, Nirvana, which became this bulldozer...
Absolutely.
...who, you know, kind of knocked everything out on the water.
I mean, I remember when the Nirvana video debuted and then...
Hold on a minute, Matt.
Let me let people know...
OK.
...where we are, what they're listening to.
We're talking with Matt Pinfield and we're looking at the 30th anniversary of MTV.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
All right.
Finish your story.

Oh, you know, I was going to say that, I mean, the - obviously Madonna - you got a letter earlier that you read about the - Madonna doing ""Like a Prayer"" and rolling around on stage at the Video Music Awards, which was really - you know, obviously, it was not only a big moment for Madonna but it was, I think, the thing that cemented the Video Music Awards as a force as well.

But, yeah, you know, the Nirvana thing, getting back to that, was - I mean, the effect that Kurt Cobain and Nirvana had when they debuted with ""Smells Like Teen Spirit"" on the channel - becoming, whether he liked it or not, very much the voice of a generation, changed the way that young people listen to music and opened the door in a way that hadn't been done, you know, I think since the 1960s, because of the fact that it became about not having to wear a uniform, not having to be a certain way, not having to be good looking...
